overview: Joel uses a devastating locust plague as a picture of coming judgment—the 'day of the LORD.' Yet he promises that God will pour out His Spirit on all people, a prophecy fulfilled at Pentecost.

verses.text: And it shall come to pass afterward, that I will pour out my Spirit on all flesh; your sons and your daughters shall prophesy, your old men shall dream dreams, and your young men shall see visions. Even on the male and female servants in those days I will pour out my Spirit.
Rend your hearts and not your garments. Return to the LORD your God, for he is gracious and merciful, slow to anger, and abounding in steadfast love.
And it shall come to pass that everyone who calls on the name of the LORD shall be saved.

passages.title: The Outpouring of the Spirit
passages.summary: God promises to pour out His Spirit on all people—young and old, male and female, slave and free. Peter quotes this at Pentecost.

facts.text: Peter's Pentecost sermon quotes Joel 2:28-32 as being fulfilled by the Holy Spirit's coming (Acts 2:16-21).
The 'day of the LORD' appears five times in this short book—a major theme of the Minor Prophets.
Joel contains both the earliest and latest prophetic phrases, making his date difficult to determine.

figures.name: Joel
figures.description: A prophet who saw beyond immediate disaster to God's ultimate purposes—judgment and restoration through His Spirit.

videos.title: Joel Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explores Joel's message about the day of the LORD and the Spirit's outpouring.
